node.title: Cricketer who exposed racist abuse apologises for historic anti-Semitic messages
node.alt: A screenshot of Azeem Rafiq speaking while sitting at a hearing
node.description: Azeem Rafiq, the former cricketer whose revelations about the racism he suffered at Yorkshire has sparked a crisis in the English game, apologises after admitting he sent anti-Semitic messages 10 years ago.
node.content:
["Azeem Rafiq, the former cricketer whose revelations about the racism he suffered at Yorkshire has sparked a crisis in the English game, has apologised after admitting\u00a0he sent anti-Semitic messages 10 years ago.", "British newspaper The Times reported it had\u00a0seen an exchange of messages sent between Rafiq and another former cricketer, Ateeq Javid, which contained disparaging comments about an unnamed Jewish person.", "Rafiq confirmed in a post on Twitter that he did send the messages, saying he had\u00a0\"absolutely no excuses\".", "\"I am ashamed of this exchange and have now deleted it so as not to cause further offence,\" Rafiq wrote.", "\"I was 19 at the time and I hope and believe I am a different person today.", "\"I am incredibly angry at myself and I apologise to the Jewish community and everyone who is rightly offended by this.\"", "Rafiq, a former England under-19 captain, testified through tears at a parliamentary hearing this week about his experiences of racism and bullying while playing for Yorkshire.", "The England and Wales Cricket Board has suspended Yorkshire from hosting international matches over its \"wholly unacceptable\" response to the racism Rafiq faced, while some sponsors are ending their deals with the club.", "", "
Azeem Rafiq apologised for anti-Semitic messages he sent 10 years ago.(Getty Images: Gareth Copley)
", "On Thursday, British Sports Minister Nigel Huddleston called for cricket to \"get its house in order\" and raised the possibility of independent regulation if it did not.", "As the racism crisis continued in English cricket, Somerset County Cricket Club also reprimanded Jack Brooks\u00a0over the fast bowler's historical posts on social media which contained racist language. The club described his comments as \"unacceptable\".", "Somerset investigated two tweets sent in 2012, when Brooks played for Northamptonshire, as well as claims that he used the name \"Steve\" to refer to Cheteshwar Pujara when the Indian Test batsman was at Yorkshire.", "The club said in a statement that Brooks, 37, was \"embarrassed and devastated that his comments offended people\".", "It said the player would participate in training on diversity and inclusion.", "", "
The Rafiq case has sparked a reckoning within English cricket.(AP / PA: Peter Powell)
", "\"He has acknowledged that, while they were made nearly a decade ago when he was less mature, the content of the posts was wrong and not in accordance with his personal values,\" the statement added.", "\"Jack has engaged honestly and openly throughout the investigation and unreservedly apologises for his past errors.\"", "\"I acknowledge that the language used in two tweets I made in 2012 was unacceptable and I deeply regret using it,\" Brooks said in a statement.", "\"I unreservedly apologise for any offence cause to anybody who may have seen these tweets.\"", "AAP"]
